subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Lexical sets in groups
msgSnippet: ... If you don t mind, I m going to address these points in the new thread, this one being so deeply nested. Paul
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>
> > It seems to me that the decisions you outline may only be determined
> > in the long run by users who make individual stylistic choices.
>
> Sure. Prescription always has its limits -- in the end, what people
> do is all that matters. But what the content of the prescription is,
> that matters too.
>
> > such as my own choice to use 'Other' instead of 'Thither' (to
> > use Jon Zuck's nomenclature) are purely aesthetic. Other choices have
> > an impact on communication across dialects.
>
> Rant: I admit that Read's keywords are sucky, verbose, and too similar
> to each other. But at least there's no dispute about them. It costs
> me extra brain cycles that I can ill afford right now to have to decode
> "Ado" or whatever into "Utter". Please let's not do that.
>
> > 1) SQUARE: use 'Ed' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
> > 2) NEAR: use 'Eat' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
> > 3) CURE: use 'Yo-yo' + 'Wool' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
>
> As I said before, Et/Ate, It/Eat, and Foot/Ooze are neutralized before
> Roe, so one of the pair has to be chosen more or less at random.
> I would much prefer consistency (either Et, It, and Foot, or else Ate,
> Eat, and Ooze), and weakly favor the second set on historical grounds.
>
> > 4) NORTH and FORCE: use 'Oak' + 'Roar'. (I am less open to persuasion.)
>
> Here the trouble is that for *most* people this distinction (historically
> Awe/Owe) is also neutralized, but for dialects including Scottish, Irish,
> Eastern New England, and parts of the American South, these sounds are
> quite different: "horse" (NORTH) does not sound the same as "hoarse"
> (FORCE), nor is "for" (NORTH) like "four" (FORCE).
>
> That being so, since the unmerged sound of NORTH is essentially THOUGHT
> + /r/, whereas FORCE is essentially GOAT + /r/, I'd prefer to reserve
> Owe-Roe for people who need a separate spelling for FORCE, and the rest
> of us use Awe-Roe for both NORTH and FORCE. Note that people who merge
> PALM and THOUGHT still retain a Awe-type vowel before /r/; that is,
> they do not merge NORTH/FORCE with START.
>
> (Second rant: FORCE is another sucky name, because "north" and "force"
> both use the "or" spelling, making it unnecessarily hard to remember which
> is which: COARSE would have been better. But standards are standards.)
>
> > 5) HAPPY: use 'Eat'. (I'm not open to persuasion.)
>
> I don't care about this one.
>

If you don't mind, I'm going to address these points in the new thread,
this one being so deeply nested.

Paul
